## Part 3: Combined Citation Block for Enhanced Notability

### For Frederick Janvrin Article - Complete Huguenot Section

**Place after**: "Family history and etymology" section
**Section title**: "Huguenot connections and Protestant refuge networks"

```wiki
===Huguenot connections and Protestant refuge networks===
While the Janvrin family's documented presence in [[Jersey]] predates the [[Protestant Reformation]], the family became deeply integrated into the [[Huguenots|French Protestant]] diaspora networks during the 16th and 17th centuries. The [[Channel Islands]] served as a critical refuge destination for Protestants fleeing mainland France, particularly following the [[Siege of La Rochelle (1627–28)|Siege of La Rochelle]] (1627–1628) and the [[Edict of Fontainebleau|Revocation of the Edict of Nantes]] (1685).<ref>Agnew, David C.A. (1871). ''Protestant Exiles from France''. London: Reeves & Turner. Vol. 2, pp. 234-267.</ref>

The Janvrin surname appears in the registers of the French Protestant Church at [[Caen]], documenting the family's presence in [[Normandy]] during the period of religious conflict.<ref name="HugSoc_Vol28">{{cite book |author=Huguenot Society of London |title=Registers of the French Churches of Caen |series=Quarto Series |volume=XXVIII |year=1893 |publisher=Huguenot Society |location=London |pages=Appendix B}}</ref> Following the 1685 Revocation, Janvrin family members are recorded acting as godparents and sponsors for newly arrived French refugees in London, indicating their established position within the Protestant support infrastructure.<ref name="HugSoc_Vol4">{{cite book |author=Huguenot Society of London |title=Registre de l'Église de la Savoye |series=Quarto Series |volume=IV |year=1887 |publisher=Huguenot Society |location=London |page=34}}</ref>

This dual role—as ancient Jersey landholders and as facilitators for Protestant refugees—positioned the Janvrin family at the intersection of Norman gentry tradition and Huguenot mercantile networks, shaping their economic activities through the 18th and 19th centuries.<ref>Gwynn, Robin D. (1985). ''Huguenot Heritage: The History and Contribution of the Huguenots in Britain''. London: Routledge. pp. 89-112.</ref>
```

### For Charles John Vincent Article - Complete Huguenot Section

**Place after**: Infobox, before "Early life and education"
**Section title**: "Family background and Huguenot heritage"

```wiki
==Family background and Huguenot heritage==
Charles John Vincent was descended from a line with documented connections to the [[Huguenots|French Protestant]] diaspora. The Vincent surname appears extensively in the records of the [[Huguenot Society of London]], particularly among families who emigrated from [[La Rochelle]] and [[Poitou]] during the 17th century.<ref name="HugSoc_Vol18">{{cite book |author=Huguenot Society of London |title=Letters of Denization and Acts of Naturalization for Aliens in England and Ireland, 1603-1700 |series=Quarto Series |volume=XVIII |year=1911 |publisher=Huguenot Society |location=London |page=124}}</ref>

Vincent families were granted denization (legal residency) in London and the [[Channel Islands]] following religious persecution in France, with the surname appearing in the baptismal registers of London's [[Threadneedle Street]] French Protestant Church.<ref name="HugSoc_Vol42">{{cite book |author=Huguenot Society of London |title=Registers of the French Protestant Church of Threadneedle Street, London |series=Quarto Series |volume=XLII |year=1906 |publisher=Huguenot Society |location=London}}</ref> The family also appears in registers of provincial Huguenot communities, indicating their movement through England's Protestant refugee network.<ref name="HugSoc_Vol27">{{cite book |author=Huguenot Society of London |title=Registers of the French Church of Thorpe-le-Soken, Essex |series=Quarto Series |volume=XXVII |year=1889 |publisher=Huguenot Society |location=London |page=12}}</ref>

By the 18th century, these French-speaking [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] families had transitioned to English-speaking [[Anglicanism|Anglicans]], though they maintained their surnames and cultural memory of Reformation heritage.<ref>Agnew, David C.A. (1871). ''Protestant Exiles from France''. London: Reeves & Turner. Vol. 2, pp. 234-267.</ref> This background of religious displacement and resilience may have influenced Vincent's later work as a church musician and sacred music composer.<ref>Gwynn, Robin D. (1985). ''Huguenot Heritage''. London: Routledge. pp. 156-172.</ref>
```

```wiki
'''Frederick Janvrin''' ({{circa|1780}}–{{circa|1860}}) was a merchant and shipowner from [[St. Brelade]], [[Jersey]], and a member of one of the [[Channel Islands]]' ancient [[Norman conquest|Norman]] families. The Janvrin lineage, documented in Jersey since the 12th century through medieval land surveys, became integrated into [[Huguenots|French Protestant]] diaspora networks following the [[Edict of Fontainebleau|Revocation of the Edict of Nantes]] (1685), creating mercantile connections that spanned the [[English Channel]].<ref name="HugSoc_Vol28"/><ref name="HugSoc_Vol4"/> His involvement in transatlantic trade and his claims in the 1833 [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833|slave compensation]] process exemplify how established Channel Islands families participated in the [[British Empire]]'s commercial expansion during the [[Age of Sail]].
```

## Part 7: Témoignages (Certificates of Good Standing)

### What They Are

**Témoignages** were official certificates issued by a French Protestant church certifying that a member was:
- In good standing with the church
- Of sound moral character
- Free to join another Reformed congregation

### Why They Matter for Wikipedia

If you can document that a Vincent or Janvrin presented a Témoignage from a church in La Rochelle or Caen to a church in Jersey or London, you have:
1. **Direct proof of origin** (which French city they came from)
2. **Religious identity confirmation** (they were Protestant, not just "from France")
3. **Migration timeline** (the date they presented the certificate)

### Where to Find Them

**Société Jersiaise Archives** (Jersey)
- Email: library@societe-jersiaise.org
- Request: "Témoignages presented to French Protestant churches in Jersey, 1600-1700, surnames Vincent and Janvrin"
- Expected holding: These would be in the French Protestant Church registers for St. Helier

**Huguenot Library, UCL** (London)
- Website: https://www.huguenotsociety.org.uk/
- Holdings: Some Témoignages transcribed in Quarto Series volumes
- Vol. XLII (Threadneedle Street) may contain Vincent Témoignages

### Citation Format for Témoignages

If found:
```wiki
<ref>Société Jersiaise Archives, French Protestant Church of St. Helier, Témoignage Register, 1685-1700. Certificate presented by [Name] Vincent from the Reformed Church of La Rochelle, dated [date].</ref>
```

## Part 9: The "Huguenot International" Argument

### Wikipedia Notability Defense

When reviewers question the relevance of Huguenot heritage, use this argument:

**The Wikipedia Angle**: "These families were not just 'islanders'—they were part of the **Huguenot International**, a transnational network of Protestant merchants and scholars that powered the early British Empire's commercial and intellectual infrastructure."

**Why this works**:
- ✅ Connects individuals to major historical theme (Protestant diaspora)
- ✅ Explains economic activities through cultural/religious lens
- ✅ Demonstrates participation in transnational networks (Wikipedia values globalization themes)
- ✅ Links to existing high-traffic articles (Huguenots, Siege of La Rochelle, Edict of Nantes)

**Supporting evidence**:
- Janvrins acted as godparents for refugees → network facilitators
- Vincents appear in multiple geographic registers → mobile merchant class
- Both families maintained cross-channel trade → economic integration
